The sluggish kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the cathode greatly limit their energy conversion efficiency. Herein, the transition metal 1,3,5-triethynylbenzene systems (TM-TEB, TM =Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Re, Os, Ir, Pt, Au) are systematically investigated by density functional theory methods, and their potential application as efficient electrocatalysts for ORR and OER is revealed. For ORR, the calculated results show that the ORR overpotentials values of Pd- and Pt-TEB are 0.34 and 0.44 V, respectively, possessing superb ORR catalytic performance. For OER, the OER overpotentials value of Pt-TEB is 0.33 V, indicating that it has excellent OER catalytic activity. In particular, the potential gap value of Pt-TEB is 0.77 V, demonstrating excellent bifunctional catalytic activity. The electrocatalyst potential of TM-TEB in the ORR/OER process is highlighted in this study, showcasing their significant promise, enhancing comprehension of TM-TEB, and offering valuable insights into possible further exploration and prospective applications for TM-TEB. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxygen reduction reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Density functional theory Transition metal 1,3,5-triethynylbenzene Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Depletion of fossil fuels and environmental pollution are two pressing global challenges facing human society in the 21st century [1,2]. The imperative is to find alternative, renewable, sustainable, and environmentally friendly energy technologies [3]. Metal-air batteries are favored for their economic and safety advantages, as they efficiently convert chemical energy into electrical energy [4-7]. However, the energy conversion efficiency is notably restricted by the sluggish kinetics in the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) processes at the cathode [8-11]. Thus, to address this challenge, it is crucial to find a multifunctional catalyst that is both efficient and cost-effective for all reactions [12]. Currently, precious metals and their oxide materials are widely used in ORR or OER processes, such as Pt and Pt-based catalysts for ORR and Ru- and Ir-based oxide catalysts for OER [13-16]. However, none of them possess bifunctional activity for both ORR and OER. Specifically, one catalyst exhibits excellent catalytic activity in the ORR process but does not demonstrate satisfactory activity in the OER process. In addition, these materials possess inherent drawbacks such as high cost, scarcity of resources, and susceptibility to poisoning, which limit their widespread application [17,18]. Therefore, searching for low-cost, efficient, and highly selective bifunctional catalysts is crucial for the further development of energy storage and conversion technologies [19,20]. In recent years, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have garnered widespread attention due to their high atomic utilization, well-defined active sites, and excellent catalytic performance. Thus, it is crucial to find a suitable substrate that can effectively adsorb individual metal atoms to ensure the stability of SACs [21]. Graphyne (GY) and its derivatives are novel two-dimensional carbon allotropes with both sp and sp2 hybridization [22,23], in which each benzene ring is linked to the neighboring benzene ring via acetylene bonds. GY and its derivatives have distinctive structural characteristics, which contribute to their outstanding chemical and physical properties, including uneven charge distribution, high conductivity, and chemical stability [24-26]. In addition, GY and its derivatives also possess significant advantages over graphene [27-31]. These unique structural features and electronic properties of GY and its derivatives make them a promising category of two-dimensional carbon materials that have found extensive applications in various fields, such as catalysis, sensors, and medicine [32-37]. Compared to other GY and its derivative materials, metallated graphyne as a novel GY derivative, is obtained by incorporating metal atoms into the graphyne framework [38]. Among them, transition metal 1,3,5-triethynylbenzene (TM-TEB) as SACs have attracted much attention in recent years [39-42]. It is composed of TM atoms and TEB molecules, forming a planar hexagonal structure with sixfold rotational symmetry. Furthermore, it combines the features of GY and single-atom metal centers, including efficient charge transfer, high electrical conductivity, chemical stability, and unsaturated metal coordination [39]. Furthermore, the unique twofold TM-alkynyl coordination bonds (−CC−TM−CC−) provide excellent electronic properties, while the uniform dispersion and extensive exposure of metal atoms contribute to enhanced durability, preventing the formation of clusters [40], thus providing more possibilities for the design of SACs. In particular, TM-TEB has been used as SACs in many fields, such as in photoelectrochemical hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) and nitrogen reduction reactions (NRR) [40,43]. Remarkably, a few TM-TEB have been successfully synthesized. For example, Zhang et al. have successfully synthesized Cu-TEB [43]. Yang et al. have successfully synthesized Ag-TEB and elucidated its structural and electronic properties in combination with density functional theory (DFT) calculations [44]. Moreover, the excellent property of TM-TEB makes them potential candidates for electrocatalysts. For example, Zhang et al. have demonstrated that Cu-TEB shows excellent performance in photoelectrochemical HER [43]. Hu et al. have extensively studied TM-TEB (transition metal atoms of the TM = 3d, 4d, and 5d series) and evaluated their viability as electrocatalysts in NRR [40]. Nevertheless, the exploration of TM-TEB systems in the field of catalysis is in its infancy, especially the research of ORR and OER is lacking. Therefore, further study of its performance in ORR and OER catalytic processes is essential for a comprehensive understanding of this class of catalysts. Inspired by the above analysis, in this work, the DFT methods are utilized to conduct a complete study of TM-TEB systems. Firstly, by computing the energy difference between TM-TEB and Ag-TEB, the stability of TM-TEB is evaluated. Secondly, by analyzing the binding behavior of reaction intermediates on the TM-TEB, the catalytic activity of TM-TEB is preliminarily evaluated. A linear relationship between the adsorption free energy of *OOH and *O with *OH is established to determine the activity descriptors. Thirdly, the TM-TEB catalysis activity is analyzed by volcano diagrams to screen out efficient electrocatalysts for ORR and OER. Then, evaluate the activity of bifunctional electrocatalysts by using the potential gap. Moreover, the electronic properties of Pt-TEB are analyzed by calculating the Mulliken charge and deformation charge density. 2 Calculational details DMol3 mode in Materials Studio was used for all calculations [45,46]. The electron exchange-correlation potential was determined by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) in the form of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional. The double numerical plus polarization (DNP) basis set was utilized to expand the atomic orbitals [47]. The convergence tolerance for energy change, maximum force, and maximum displacement were 2.0 × 10-5 Ha, 0.004 Ha Å-1, and 0.005 Å, respectively. At the same time, sampled using a 2 × 2 × 1 k-point mesh based on the Monkhorst-Pack grid to the Brillouin zone. Based on the successful synthesis of Ag-TEB in the experiment and its demonstrated good stability. Thus, to evaluate the stability of the catalyst, the energy difference between TM-TEB and Ag-TEB is calculated [44]. The specific expression of energy difference (E d) is as follows: (1) E d = E TM − TEB + 3 E Ag − E Ag − TEB − 3 E TM where E TM-TEB, E TM, E Ag, and E Ag-TEB are the energies of TM-TEB, transition metal atoms, Ag atoms, and Ag-TEB, respectively. If the calculated E d is a negative value, the replacement of Ag on Ag-TEB by other metal atoms is energetically favorable. In addition, the first-principle molecular dynamics simulations are conducted for 2 ps at 300 K to assess its dynamic stability. The overall ORR in the acidic environment is as follows: (2) O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2O The four-electron pathway of the ORR process through the following steps: (* indicates adsorption sites): (3) * + O2 + H+ + e− → *OOH (4) *OOH + H+ + e− → *O + H2O (5) *O + H+ + e− → *OH (6) *OH + H+ + e− → * + H2O The electrochemical process of OER can be seen as the inverse of ORR. Below is the overall reaction involved in the OER process: (7) 2H2O → O2 + 4H+ + 4e− The four-electron pathway of OER involves four elementary reaction steps as follows: (8) * + H2O →*OH + H+ + e− (9) *OH → *O + H+ + e− (10) *O + H2O → *OOH + H+ + e− (11) *OOH → * + O2 + H+ + e− For each elementary step, the Gibbs free energy ΔG of the reaction is defined as follows [48]: (12) Δ G = Δ ZPE + Δ E − T Δ S + Δ G P H + Δ G U where ΔZPE, ΔE, and ΔS are the zero-point energy, difference in the electronic energy, and entropy, respectively. T is 298.15 K. ΔG PH represents the Gibbs free energy with respect to the concentration of H+, defined as ΔG PH = k B Tln(10) × pH, where k B denotes the Boltzmann constant. ΔG U is given by the equation ΔG U = −neU, where n represents the number of electrons transferred, and U stands for the electrode potential. The method proposed by Nørskov et al. enables the computation of the Gibbs free energy for these basic steps [49]. The ORR overpotential (η ORR) and OER overpotential (η OER) are calculated as: (13) η ORR = ( Δ G ORR max / e ) + 1.23 (14) η OER = ( Δ G OER max / e ) − 1.23 Defining the potential gap (ΔE) to demonstrate the bifunctional catalytic activity of ORR and OER [50], and below is the formula for this calculation: (15) Δ E = η ORR + η OER 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Geometry and stability of the TM-TEB TM-TEB are composed of TM atoms and TEB molecules, which are linked together by the twofold TM-alkynyl coordination bonds to form a planar hexagonal structure with a sixfold rotational symmetry, as shown in Fig. 1 a. The presence of uniformly distributed macropores and a π-conjugated system enhances both mass transfer and charge transport efficiency, rendering it a highly promising catalyst with high-performance potential. All considered TM are displayed in Fig. 1b, where Tc, Cd, and Hg are excluded due to toxicity or radioactivity. After optimizing the structures, it can be observed that apart from Co-, Ni-, Cu-, Zn-, Re-, and Os-TEB, the other structures undergo almost no deformation. Consequently, Co-, Ni-, Cu-, Zn-, Re-, and Os-TEB will not be considered in the following calculations. For all TM-TEB systems, the bond length between C1 and C2 is 1.232 to 1.255 Å, indicating a triple bond for C1−C2, while the bond length between C2 and C3 is 1.401 to 1.433 Å, representing a single bond for C2−C3. Moreover, the bond length between TM atoms and C1 ranges from 1.838 to 2.285 Å. These results are consistent with previous studies [40]. This demonstrates that the strong chemical bonding interactions ensure the stability of the structure. The satisfactory stability of TM-TEB is an important prerequisite for them to be excellent catalysts. Firstly, we calculated the E d to assess the stability of TM-TEB. The results are shown in Fig. 2 . Obviously, all E d values exhibit negativity, which indicates that replacing TM atoms with Ag atom provides energetically advantageous, i.e., all the investigated TM-TEB have satisfactory thermodynamic stabilities. Then, the thermodynamic stability of TM-TEB is evaluated by using first-principles molecular dynamics simulations at 300 K. Taking Pd-TEB (with the most positive E d value) as a representative, the calculation result is shown in Fig. 3 a. The total energy of the systems exhibits minimal variation, and the Pd-TEB catalyst structure remains unchanged even after 2 ps simulation at 300 K, suggesting that the atoms vibrate within the lattice sites to preserve the structures. Results of the above indicate that Pd-TEB possesses excellent stability. This further confirms the result of E d. Additionally, the intrinsic reason for the stability of Pd-TEB is explored by calculating its DOS, and the result is plotted in Fig. 3b. There is a remarkable orbital overlap between the d orbital of Pd atom and the p orbital of C1 atom within the energy is −6 to 0 eV, showing strong interaction between Pd atom and C1 atom, resulting in good stability of Pd-TEB. 3.2 Binding of reaction intermediates In this work, the four-electron pathway of ORR and OER is noticed and the schematic diagram for ORR and OER processes is exhibited in Fig. 4 a. For ORR, the process consists of four reaction steps. The first step is the protonation of activated O2 molecule to form *OOH. The second step is the breaking of the O−O bond in *OOH, resulting in the formation of *O and one H2O molecule. The third step is the protonation of *O, forming *OH. The fourth step is the reduction of *OH, producing another H2O molecule. For OER, the process is * + H2O →*OH → *O → *OOH → * + O2. In the catalytic process, the adsorption behaviors of key intermediates (*OOH, *O, and *OH) on TM-TEB can remarkably influence ORR and OER catalytic activity. Therefore, the adsorption free energy of reaction intermediates (ΔG species, i.e., ΔG *OH, ΔG *O, and ΔG *OOH) values are calculated and depicted in Fig. 4b-d. According to the principle of Sabatier [51], the ideal catalyst should have a moderate binding strength with the reaction intermediates. Excessive strength or weakness in binding could compromise the efficiency of catalytic of both the ORR and OER processes. The more positive the ΔG species values, the weaker the adsorption of intermediate products by TM-TEB. When U is 0 V, for optimal performance, the ideal energy values for ΔG *OOH, ΔG *O, and ΔG *OH are 3.69 eV, 2.46 eV, and 1.23 eV, respectively. If the ΔG *OOH, ΔG *O, and ΔG *OH values on TM-TEB are close to the ideal catalysts, they may possess excellent ORR and OER catalytic potential. It is worth noting that the ΔG *OOH, ΔG *O, and ΔG *OH values of Pd- and Pt-TEB are closer to that of the ideal catalyst than that of the remaining TM-TEB. In particular, for Pd-TEB, the ΔG *OOH, ΔG *O, and ΔG *OH values are respectively 3.81, 2.92, and 0.96 eV, which are 0.12, 0.46, and 0.27 eV different from the ΔG *OOH, ΔG *O, and ΔG *OH values of the ideal catalyst, respectively, indicating that it may possess excellent catalytic potential of ORR and OER. For Ir-TEB, its adsorption strength for the reaction intermediates is much stronger than that of the ideal catalyst, which will be unfavorable to the ORR and OER processes. Then, we probe the adsorption free energy relationships for *OOH, *O, and *OH in Fig. 5 a-b. The expression for the linear correlation between ΔG *OH and ΔG *OOH is: ΔG *OOH = 0.88ΔG *OH + 2.87 eV, with a coefficient of determination (R2) of 0.96. The formula for the linear correlation between ΔG *OH and ΔG *O is: ΔG *O = 1.83ΔG *OH + 0.71 eV, with a coefficient of determination (R2) of 0.97. Both ΔG *OOH and ΔG *O exhibit a strong linear correlation with ΔG *OH, indicating that TM-TEB with strong binding strength to *OH will also demonstrate strong binding strengths to *O and *OOH. Hence, ΔG *OH can be utilized as an activity descriptor further to investigate the ORR and OER activities of TM-TEB. 3.3 Catalytic activity of ORR/OER To delve deeper into the catalytic activity of ORR and OER, η ORR and η OER values are calculated for all catalysts in Fig. 6 a. The smaller the η ORR/η OER value of TM-TEB, the better the ORR/OER catalytic activity. For ORR, Pt(111) is utilized as the base reference with an η ORR value of 0.45 V [15]. Obviously, the η ORR values of Pd- and Pt-TEB are 0.34 and 0.44 V, respectively, which is even lower than the value of Pt(111) (η ORR = 0.45 V). For OER, we use RuO2(110) and IrO2(110) as the base references with η OER values of 0.37 and 0.56 V [14]. It can be observed that the η OER value of Pt-TEB is 0.33 V, which is 0.04 V smaller than RuO2(110) (η OER = 0.37 V), indicating excellent performance as a catalyst for OER. In addition, the volcano diagrams of η (η ORR and η OER) and ∆G *OH on TM-TEB are constructed as shown in Fig. 6b. For ORR, from left to right, the value of ∆G *OH gradually increases, while the value of η ORR decreases first and then increases. That is, TM-TEB with moderate OH adsorption strength exhibits the best ORR catalytic activity. In particular, when the value of ∆G *OH is 1.09 eV, the catalyst can reach the optimal η ORR value of 0.14 V. Similarly, for OER, when ∆G *OH is 0.82 eV, the η OER value is 0.16 V. In this work, a catalyst demonstrating substantial electrocatalytic prowess for both reactions is termed a bifunctional catalyst. Thus, the ΔE is calculated as an indicator to describe the bifunctional electrocatalytic activity, as shown in Fig. 7 . It is well known that the catalyst's bifunctional activity is increased with decreasing ΔE values. The results indicate that the ΔE value for Pt-TEB is 0.77 V, indicating that it can exhibit excellent bifunctional catalytic activity. It is comparable to those of reported ORR and OER bifunctional catalysts, such as Co-doped g-C3N4 (ΔE = 1.20 V) [52], Mn x O y /NC (ΔE = 0.87 V) [53], the Fe-based covalent organic framework (ΔE = 0.86 V) [54], and CoN x -gra (ΔE = 1.06 V) [55]. To further explore the catalytic mechanism of ORR and OER, we construct a free energy diagram for Pt-TEB at U = 0 and 1.23 V, illustrating the potential-determining step (PDS), as depicted in Fig. 8 . The PDS is the step with the maximum ΔG ORR and ΔG OER values. We select Pt-TEB as an example because they possess great ORR and OER catalytic activity. For ORR, at U = 0 V, the curves show a decreasing trend, suggesting that the reaction can be catalyzed on Pt-TEB spontaneously. The PDS for Pt-TEB is the step of *OH → * + H2O. When U = 1.23 V, it can be found that only the step *OH→H2O is uphill, indicating that this step is endothermic. Therefore, this step requires more additional energy, thus suggesting that the PDS of Pt-TEB is determined by the reduction step of *OH. Similarly, for OER, the PDS for Pt-TEB is *O → *OOH. 3.4 Electronic properties analysis Based on previous research, the uneven charge distribution, high chemical stability, and adjustable adsorption strength of catalyst configurations affect the catalytic performance of the catalyst [56-59]. Since Pt-TEB has excellent OER and ORR catalytic activities, it is essential to analyze its electronic properties to explore the factors affecting its catalytic activity. Thus, the Milliken charge and deformation charge density are calculated in Fig. 9 . The Pt-TEB system is divided into three parts: Pt atom, TEB molecule, and intermediates. The results of charge transfer are displayed in Fig. 9a. Obviously, the charge of Pt and intermediates fluctuates clearly, while the charge of TEB changes very small. This means that charge transfer occurs mainly between Pt atom and intermediates. Meanwhile, the results of deformed charge density are shown in Fig. 9b. The blue region signifies electron density accumulation, whereas the yellow zone denotes electron density depletion. Clearly, the direct contact of the electron density region between Pt atom and intermediates results in a significant charge transfer. This charge transfer not only enhances the stability of the intermediate but also promotes a strong interaction between the intermediate and the Pt atom. This strong interaction may be an important factor affecting the catalytic activity. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have systematic explored TM-TEB as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for catalyzing ORR and OER using DFT methods. Firstly, the E d between TM-TEB (TM =Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ru, Rh, Pd, Re, Os, Ir, Pt, Au) and Ag-TEB is calculated to evaluate the stability of all TM-TEB. The findings indicated that all TM-TEB processes exhibit high stability. Secondly, the linear relationship between ΔG *OOH and ΔG *O with ΔG *OH indicated that ΔG *OH is the active descriptor to determine the ORR and OER properties of TM-TEB. Thirdly, for ORR, Pt-TEB (η ORR = 0.44 V) and Pd-TEB (η ORR = 0.34 V) demonstrate excellent catalytic activity, which is even lower than the value of Pt(111). For OER, the Pt-TEB (η OER = 0.33 V) demonstrates satisfactory OER catalytic activity with overpotential values comparable to the well-known catalysts RuO2(110) and IrO2(110). Moreover, Pt-TEB possesses the lowest ΔE value with 0.77 V, showing that it has highly efficient bifunctional catalytic activity. Moreover, the results of Mulliken charge and deformation charge indicated that the strong interaction between Pt atom and intermediates is due to the obvious charge transfer between them. The insights and accomplishments attained from this study are anticipated to enhance comprehension regarding the substantial promise of TM-TEB systems as electrocatalysts for both the ORR and OER processes. coredata.dc:description: The sluggish kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the cathode greatly limit their energy conversion efficiency. Herein, the transition metal 1,3,5-triethynylbenzene systems (TM-TEB, TM =Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Re, Os, Ir, Pt, Au) are systematically investigated by density functional theory methods, and their potential application as efficient electrocatalysts for ORR and OER is revealed. For ORR, the calculated results show that the ORR overpotentials values of Pd- and Pt-TEB are 0.34 and 0.44 V, respectively, possessing superb ORR catalytic performance. For OER, the OER overpotentials value of Pt-TEB is 0.33 V, indicating that it has excellent OER catalytic activity. In particular, the potential gap value of Pt-TEB is 0.77 V, demonstrating excellent bifunctional catalytic activity. The electrocatalyst potential of TM-TEB in the ORR/OER process is highlighted in this study, showcasing their significant promise, enhancing comprehension of TM-TEB, and offering valuable insights into possible further exploration and prospective applications for TM-TEB.
